articles.headline: Iran Sets Free 15 Britons Seized at Sea
articles.snippet: British sailors and marines will arrive in London today on a commercial flight from Tehran, resolving a diplomatic impasse that began on March 23.
articles.abstract: British sailors and marines will arrive in London today on a commercial flight from Tehran, resolving a diplomatic impasse that began on March 23.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Thursday, April 5 — Iran on Thursday morning released the 15 British sailors and marines it seized at sea nearly two weeks ago, resolving a diplomatic impasse with what Iran’s president called a “gift” to the British people.

articles.headline: Daimler’s Chief Confirms Talks to Sell Chrysler
articles.snippet: The company confirmed for the first time that it is in negotiations about a deal for the troubled American unit.
articles.abstract: The company confirmed for the first time that it is in negotiations about a deal for the troubled American unit.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN, April 4 — DaimlerChrysler insists it is keeping all options open for the future of the Chrysler Group. But judging by its tense annual meeting here on Wednesday, Daimler’s marriage to Chrysler is already finished — except for the ink on the divorce papers.

articles.headline: TiVo Plays a Trump Card: Web Smarts
articles.snippet: TiVo has been quietly adding features that take the machine well beyond its original function as a video recorder.
articles.abstract: TiVo has been quietly adding features that take the machine well beyond its original function as a video recorder.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is it with the rash of new set-top boxes lately? One recent box brings the best of the Internet to your TV screen, like podcasts, Web videos and Internet radio. Another one is a video recorder that you can operate from anywhere in the world (for example, tell it to record a show), using only your cellphone.

articles.headline: Israel’s Protests Are Said to Stall Gulf Arms Sale
articles.snippet: An arms-sale package that the U.S. is planning to offer Persian Gulf allies has been delayed because of objections from Israel.
articles.abstract: An arms-sale package that the U.S. is planning to offer Persian Gulf allies has been delayed because of objections from Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 — A major arms-sale package that the Bush administration is planning to offer Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf allies to deter Iran has been delayed because of objections from Israel, which says that the advanced weaponry would erode its military advantage over its regional rivals, according to senior United States officials.
articles.byline: By David S. Cloud and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Early ’08 Fund-Raising Has Clear Blue Tint
articles.snippet: Democrats raised a total of $78 million, compared with just over $51 million by their rivals, figures show.
articles.abstract: Democrats raised a total of $78 million, compared with just over $51 million by their rivals, figures show.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, April 4 — For anyone looking for a sign of the health of the Democratic Party going into the 2008 presidential campaign, it came Wednesday with the last of the fund-raising figures reported by the major presidential candidates.

articles.headline: Trust Sued Over Backing Retiree Plan
articles.snippet: The lawsuit contends that the New York State United Teachers breached its fiduciary duty when it accepted millions in exchange for endorsing products to plan members.
articles.abstract: The lawsuit contends that the New York State United Teachers breached its fiduciary duty when it accepted millions in exchange for endorsing products to plan members.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan last week contends that a retirement plan offered by the New York State United Teachers breached its fiduciary duty when it accepted millions of dollars in payments from an investment firm in exchange for endorsing the firm’s products to plan members.

articles.headline: Shell Expects Full Output From Nigeria
articles.snippet: Shell expects to resume oil production in Nigeria within five to six months after shutting down operations because of militant violence.
articles.abstract: Shell expects to resume oil production in Nigeria within five to six months after shutting down operations because of militant violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 4 — A year after being forced to shut more than half of its oil operations in Nigeria because of militant violence, Royal Dutch Shell says that it has reached an agreement with local communities allowing it to return safely to the Niger Delta and that it expects to resume full production within five to six months.

articles.headline: Injured in Iraq, a Soldier Is Shattered at Home
articles.snippet: Sam Ross’s story, with its heart-rending arc from hardscrabble childhood to hardscrabble adulthood.
articles.abstract: Sam Ross’s story, with its heart-rending arc from hardscrabble childhood to hardscrabble adulthood.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNBAR, Pa. — Blinded and disabled on the 54th day of the war in Iraq, Sam Ross returned home to a rousing parade that outdid anything this small, depressed Appalachian town had ever seen. “Sam’s parade put Dunbar on the map,” his grandfather said.

articles.headline: At Wal-Mart, Lessons in Self-Help
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart has quietly introduced an ambitious self-help project to make its workers more productive.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart has quietly introduced an ambitious self-help project to make its workers more productive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employees at a Wal-Mart near Saratoga, Fla., have started an aerobics class twice a week in their break room. Wal-Mart workers in Denver are reimbursed for taking public transportation to and from work. And the staff at a Sam’s Club in Indianapolis now takes a daily walk around the perimeter of the store.

articles.headline: Ford Chief Sticking to His Road Map for Turnaround
articles.snippet: Ford’s chief executive insisted that he saw no need for deeper cuts beyond those scheduled in the company’s recovery plan.
articles.abstract: Ford’s chief executive insisted that he saw no need for deeper cuts beyond those scheduled in the company’s recovery plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company’s sales continue to fall and no one is predicting a North American profit before 2009. But the chief executive insisted yesterday that he saw no need for deeper cuts beyond those scheduled in its recovery plan.
